comments.text: I am willing to pay all my taxes if this is the good stuff I'm gonna get.﻿
comments.author: Gene L.

comments.text:
I think it is worth mentioning many Finnish educators had stated that their 
education reform is unprecedented and may not be replicable everywhere. 
Their education is successful base on the need of Finland at this 
particular point of history.

For instance, it wouldn't be wise to apply the same system to parochial 
states that focus largely on agriculture, since you will be directing 
majority of your labour force into high tech industry which the country 
doesn't even have.

The point being, yes equality is very good, but if other states want to 
adopt the same thing they should be a little more creative in terms of how 
they want to implement this system. It does not need to be exactly the 
same.﻿
comments.author: Gene L.

comments.text: It used to make good results, now it's going to shit.﻿
comments.author: chaistan

comments.text:
+Aletheia Humas Eleutheroo You have one guy's opinion. Now it is time for 
some data. That post was published in 2013. Here are the 2011 PIRLS and 
TIMSS results..
8th grade:
Math = 7th
Natural science = 4th
(https://ktl.jyu.fi/pirls-timss/kahdeksannen-luokan-taulukot)

4th grade:
Reading = 3rd
Math = 8th
Natural science = 3rd
(https://ktl.jyu.fi/pirls-timss/4taulukot)


The only things where we failed at, were the enthusiasm, motivation and 
dedication. We beat US, we beat the Swedish and we beat the English in the 
results. Your argument fails!﻿

comments.author: Kame Reconi

comments.text:
+Aletheia Humas Eleutheroo Are you really that stupid or just dishonest? 
Your claim was that "Finland's scores have gone down in other tests [than 
PISA] since implementing this scam" and you offered a link that talks about 
TIMSS results. So I showed you the latest TIMSS results in which Finns seem 
to do just fine. And you are just going to ignore it?

"They don't teach anyone how to think for themselves or how to do research" 
And yet Finland has the most researchers in R&D (per million people). I 
don't think that you know anything about Finland.
comments.author: VJScope

comments.text:
How is 2011 data more relevant than 2013 data? And 1 or 2 tests are easy to 
teach for, which is what almost every education system has become. Teach to 
the test, not to inform. They don't teach anyone how to think for 
themselves or how to do research, and your numbers say nothing of higher 
grades or of engineering etc.

comments.text:
Fun fact - Finland ripped off the entire system from the German Democratic 
Republic.
Not exactly one-by-one, but in the main points. GDR still had a system of 
small rewards, such as cute stickers of woodland animals and bees, and if 
you did extraordinarily well, they would give you ribbons, medals, books 
and such.﻿

comments.author: MetaKnight964

comments.text:
Stop politicizing everything.. Also I fail to see why excellence is a bad 
thing. And Finland isn't like the U.S. which is why the educational system 
has differences but being liberals you probably didn't bother doing any 
research nor did you put any thought into what you said. One more thing, 
you liberals hate individualism and freedom which is why your beloved 
public schools are terrible.﻿
comments.author: MetaKnight964

comments.text:
Ha. Then why is Finland better than America in that aspect? Well done, 
you've managed to ignore the facts and point out that Finland and the 
United States of America are two different countries. What I don't 
understand is why you're looking at the fact that Finland has an education 
system that works and doesn't work the children to death, doesn't put the 
rich before everyone else, doesn't send them to school until they're seven, 
has no clothing restrictions, no homework, doesn't teach kids to want to be 
better than everyone else, and levels the playing field in a way that your 
(and my country, the UK) has failed for years, and you take one look at it 
down your nose, and you say what you just said. Why would you want to 
settle for what you have now if Finland's system actually is excellence? 
And by being excellent, they produce educated citizens that are excellent 
at what they want to do.
I don't see why their political views have anything to do with the problem 
at hand in your country. "You liberals hate individualism and freedom" then 
why are they promoting a system that encourages the freedom to be an 
individual and have a fair chance at pursuing your dream job, and you are 
promoting a system that allows rich people to send their kids to a school 
that gives them a better education and make their kids rich by proxy, 
putting a significant gap between the elite and the common folk?

Finland's system is about equal opportunity. American-style educational 
systems are about keeping the elite on top.

distinction between the East Asian model being literally a killer (you only

much freedom to the student, without compromising support and guidance. I 
am going to be teaching English in Shanghai as of next year - if anyone has 
any info or advice please reply. ﻿

comments.author: Redman Republic

comments.text:
+KapeDude Your English is great, my Finnish friend! I'm from Pakistan 
originally, and I've been living in America for 16 years. At first, the 
education system here was excellent. I remember when I first started going 
to school, the teachers here really cared about me learning English, and I 
picked it up in about a year! But after all of these years later, most 
teachers don't care about teaching, because the system in America doesn't 
care about teachers. Otherwise, teachers would be making a great salary and 
would be highly respected. And I imagine that in Finland, the reason why 
teachers do an excellent job in educating the younger generations is 
because Finnish society respects the teaching profession, and teachers earn 
a decent living wage. The only institution still keeping America alive are 
its universities, but sadly, they've become a profitable business :(
comments.author: thearchitect27

comments.author: Ada Wong

comments.text:
Is it not worth it though? If you have highly educated young people with a 
great self esteem and respect for one another - equality being the key (you 
have royalty sitting alongside the poorest children in classes over there) 
- how can that not be worth the peoples' investment? It all contributes to 
a better community, atmosphere, quality of life. So what if there is less 
to spend on nanny state policing and excessive defense, if you have social 
cohesion there is little need for much of a police service. Spend the money 
where it counts - education, health, housing, science.
comments.author: glowy303

comments.text:
View of Finnish teachers versus view of Pasi Sahlberg
Oxford- Prof. Jennifer Chung ( AN INVESTIGATION OF REASONS FOR FINLAND’S 
SUCCESS IN PISA (University of Oxford 2008).
“Many of the teachers mentioned the converse of the great strength of 
Finnish education (= de grote aandacht voor kinderen met leerproblemen) as 
the great weakness.  Jukka S. (BM) believes that school does not provide 
enough challenges for intelligent students: “I think my only concern is 
that we give lots of support to those pupils who are underachievers, and we 
don’t give that much to the brightest pupils.  I find it a problem, since I 
think, for the  future of a whole nation, those pupils who are really the 
stars should be supported, given some more challenges, given some more 
difficulty in their exercises and so on.  To not just spend  their time 
here but to make some effort and have the idea to become something, no 
matter what field you are choosing, you must not only be talented like they 
are, but work hard.  That is needed. “
Pia (EL)  feels that the schools do not motivate very intelligent students 
to work.   She thinks the schools should provide more challenges for the 
academically talented students.  In fact, she thinks the current school 
system in Finland does not provide well for its students.  Mixed-ability 
classrooms, she feels, are worse than the previous selective system: “ I 
think this school is for nobody.  That is my private opinion. Actually I 
think so, because when you have all these people at mixed levels in your 
class, then you have to concentrate on the ones who need the most help, of 
course.  Those who are really good, they get lazy. “
Pia believes these students become bored and lazy, and float through school 
with no study skills.  Jonny (EM) describes how comprehensive education 
places the academically gifted at a disadvantage: “We have lost a great 
possibility when we don’t have the segregated levels of math and natural 
sciences… That should be once again taken back and started with.  The good 
talents are now torturing themselves with not very interesting education 
and  teaching in classes that aren’t for their best.
Pia (EL) finds the PISA frenzy about Finland amusing, since she believes 
the schools have declined in recent years: “I think [the attention] is 
quite funny because school isn’t as good as it used to be … I used to be 
proud of being a teacher and proud of this school, but I can’t say I ’m 
proud any more.”
Aino (BS) states that the evenness and equality of the education system has 
a “dark side.” Teaching to the “middle student” in a class of heterogeneous 
ability bores the gifted students, who commonly do not perform well in 
school.  Maarit (DMS) finds teaching heterogeneous classrooms very 
difficult.  She admits that dividing the students into ability levels would 
make the teaching easier, but worries that it may affect the self-esteem of 
the weaker worse than a more egalitarian system        Similarly, Terttu 
(FMS) thinks that the class size is a detriment to the students’ learning.  
Even though Finnish schools have relatively small class sizes, she thinks 
that a group of twenty is too large, since she does not have time for all 
of the students: “You don’t have enough time for everyone … All children 
have to be in the same class.  That is not so nice.  You have the better 
pupils.  I can’t give them as much as I want.  You have to go so slowly in 
the classroom.”   Curiously, Jukka E. (DL) thinks that the special 
education students need more support and the education system needs to 
improve in that area.
Miikka (FL) describes how he will give extra work to students who want to 
have more academic challenges, but admits that “they can get quite good 
grades, excellent grades, by doing nothing actually, or very little.”  
Miikka (FL) describes discussion in educational circles about creating 
schools and universities for academically talented students: 3 Everyone has 
the same chances…One problem is that it can be  too easy for talented 
students.  There has been now discussion in Finland if there should be 
schools and universities for talented students… I think it will happen, but 
I don’t know if it is good, but it will happen, I think so.  I am also 
afraid there will be private schools again in Finland in the future … 
[There] will be more rich people and more poor people, and then will come 
so [many] problems in comprehensive schools that some day quite  soon … 
parents will demand that we should have private schools  again, and that is 
quite sad.
 
Linda (AL), however, feels the love of reading has declined in the younger 
generation, as they tend to gravitate more to video games and television.   
Miikka (FL), also a teacher of mother tongue, also cites a decline in 
reading interest and an increase of video game and computer play.  Saij a 
(BL) agrees. As a teacher of Finnish, she feels that she has difficulty 
motivating her students to learn: “I think my subject is not the … easiest 
one to teach.   They don’t read so much, newspapers or novels.”  Her 
students, especially the boys, do not like their assignments in Finnish 
language.  She also thinks the respect for teachers has declined in this 
past generation.  Miikka (FL) also thinks his students do not respect their 
teachers: “They don’t respect the teachers.  They respect them very little 
…  I think it has changed a lot in recent years.  In Helsinki, it was 
actually earlier.  When I came here six years ago, I thought this  was 
heaven.   I thought it was incredible, how the children were  like that 
after Helsinki, but now I think it is the same.
Linda (AL) notes deficiency in the amount of time available for subjects.  
With more time, she would implement more creative activities, such as 
speech and drama, into her lessons.  Saij a (BL) also thinks that her 
students need more arts subjects like drama and art.  She worries that they 
consider mathematics as the only important subject.  Shefeels countries 
such as Sweden, Norway, and England have better arts programs than in 
Finnish schools.  Arts subjects, according to Saij a, help the students get 
to know themselves.  Maarit (DMS), a Finnish-speaker, thinks that schools 
need to spend more time cultivating social skills.﻿
comments.author: Raf Feys

comments.text:
Study Oxford-prof Jennifer Chung:  The interviewees (Finland-teachers) 
mention  its great faults, the lack of support for the academically 
talented.  In this situation, one can observe a limitation of egalitarian 
values.  The interviewees also consistently mention the students’ lack of 
enjoyment in school. "﻿

comments.author: Amelia Merirand

comments.text:
I adore the Finnish model but "homogeneous" in this context refers to the 
language barrier. Nearly every child who starts school in Finland has 
Finnish as their first language. Although Other languages such as English, 
French, German and Russian are very widely spoken, their official language 
is spoken in a very high percentage of young school-age children. Compare 
this to the USA where Spanish and Arabic are increasingly common first 
languages for students (and it's the same in Australia). It's very 
difficult to have students participating in the teaching of other students 
(part of the Finnish model) when they don't speak the same language. ﻿

comments.author: Sami Sund

comments.text:
I remember when I was a kid.
The teachers made e.g. math a competition from we were about 7.
They would have these competition with the whole class were it was all 
about being fastest in solving arithmetics, equations etc
Now they continued that kind of teaching more or less when I got older too.

I lost touch with math completetly. Young boys(more than girls), and 
especially pubertal boys, want to excel in something, they want to show 
off. Either being the funny guy, the best footballer, best skater, anything.
In doing so, they also shy away from a field which is taken, that is, has 
strong competition. It's more cost effective to find an opportunity to 
shine other places. Much of this happens unconsciously, and can easily by 
understood from a evolutionary point of view. 
The ones who end up exceling in, say math, are the ones who "won" the field 
from very early on, and thus have a motivation to keep their top spot.
Now kids still remain in activities in which they are not the best, maybe 
even the poorest, say, in sports, but there is a big difference, and that 
is that these activities often have a social aspect. Testing in schools 
usually don't have this social aspect when it is competition focused.

Many give up, because they find no gain when they can't be the best. They 
can even find it humiliating to be mediocre, and with that attitude you 
will never have any prospects of excelling in school.

Much of the degrees from I was 15 to 18 years old I had to take up later on.
I didn't really understand simple math until I was 21.
I realized then that I wasn't at all dumb in simple math and analytical 
math(the latter which is what really counts in higher education), as I had 
always thought.
I started to find it very interesting as well, and now I'm studying physics 
at the university.

I believe what happens is a, mostly unconscious, evolutionary thing, in 
which we step aside when we sense that we can't win. Because one does not 
want to show oneself as a beta male, in any frame. This is especially the 
case in pubertal boys.
It's a short term risk-reward strategy, which probably had an important 
function in archaic humans. But it serves little to no function in modern 
society, were schooling is part of a long term strategy.

Thus promoting competition in schooling will make this short term 
risk-reward strategy more relevant and prevalent.﻿

comments.text:
Well I wouldn't have even guessed that Finland was this high on the 
ranking. I don't even have a clue why this system is called so good, I mean 
we're pretty much given the longest pauses ever and the learning pace is 
unbelievably slow all of the time.

But the recent drop in the rankings for Finland is quite possibly because 
the attitude of this specific age group is not entirely on the "Alright, I 
can give it a shot." level, and that results in them saying "Well, just 
fuck it.". Sure I'm myself a part of it, and you can argue that I'm 
unbelievably lazy and also say the "Naah, I'll do it later" but that's a 
part of it, everyone says it (at some point). Despite that I rank quite 
high among the students in my year (Not a full 10 out of 10, but my average 
is more like 9,2 out of 10). If I were to compare the other "lazier" 
students to me (Oh and as I said I'm also lazy as hell, don't take me wrong 
here), the difference would be that I actually care (sometimes... o.o) and 
am willing to learn more. It's just not the educational system that can 
blow up, the people are also a part of the reason why it's doing well or 
bad.

I suppose people just aren't that self-imposed anymore (Well I can't really 
know if we ever were). I learn japanese on my free time, when I feel like 
it, and it doesn't take any of my time away and is genuinely fun. You 
should find something like that too, which is actually fun and useful, it's 
really rewarding I suggest that to everyone.

The point is, it can be a long and painful fall from the top, unless we 
change our attitude.

These are my thoughts on this matter, not that I can express it well, but I 
gave it a shot. Just a way to pass my holiday , eh?﻿

comments.author: burr697

comments.text:
I agree we should adopt the Finland model.

The resistance comes in the form of those who don't want the US to be 
homogenous.  They don't want to help the poor, they don't want to help 
other races.  In fact, they either want those people to be kicked out of 
the country, ignored or just treated as second class citizens.  This is a 
huge problem in the USA.

There are also the issues of money and religion.  These are probably even 
bigger obstacles- although they are related to the first problem.  But the 
issue of a heterogeneous society is sort of going away slowly.  I mean, 
people don't hate as much as they used to.  But the separation because of 
religion and for financial gain will continue and exists within 
egalitarian- minded people.

Money is the biggest problem.  People love capitalism and look for it to 
solve all problems.  It is really the american religion, or it is the 
modern religion- and the US is the leader symbolically and actually in 
terms of dollars and financial leaders on wall street and ceos of the 
largest companies and the most rich people if not the richest people. 
 There are a few people richer than "Americans", but there are more rich 
people in the US than elsewhere overall.  Also, the US was traditionally 
where people went to get rich, and probably, even though social mobility 
has become very poor in the US, people still come here to get really rich, 
and it's easier to succeed because of the rules in place that favor certain 
kinds of business enterprises and the people who have that kind of 
expertise.

So it's no surprise that people are at least open to considering a 
capitalist approach to education.  The average person has probably not 
given up on public education, but there has been a sustained push to 
discredit public education and the teacher's unions. But the real problem 
is that there is a huge incentive to privatize education, because that 
could mean huge profits, subsidized by Uncle Sam.  It's not really the 
people who are leading this- they are being led by those who want to 
destroy the public contract and those who want to make big bucks off of 
privatization.  So, other systems, like the Finland system, are unlikely to 
be adopted until people realize privatization isn't very good for our kids. 
 And of course, not everyone even thinks of US children as "our" kids. 
 They prefer to think of most of American kids as unworthy to be "American".

Religion is a big problem mainly because the right wing and the rich have 
effectively worked their messages into the mainstream so that they can use 
religious leaders to spread their ideology through religion.  They have 
been working hard on this since the 60's and have mostly succeeded. Which 
is why poor and middle class consistently vote against their own interests 
in the US, and in favor of policies that help the rich get richer and help 
the rich to take from the poor.  And it's why people are moving towards 
privatization in education- and I include charter schools in that equation. 
 It's part of the spectrum from public to private.

So it's going to be difficult for something like the Finland model of 
education to take hold in the US.  I do have hope for this happening in the 
long run, however.  In the short run, the only way this could happen is for 
some kind of movement or inspirational leader or leaders to raise the issue 
and change the minds of the people and the decision makers in the US.  I 
don't see that happening yet.﻿
comments.author: AWildBard

comments.text:
I like to look at Scandinavia as a sort of experimental region, it is easy 
to see what works and what doesnt on such small scale.
Its also amusing to look at Sweden which is using the american template for 
education and has fallen alot on the international rankings.
In 2013, the Swedish gov even called a crisis meeting to curb the negative 
trend while at the same time finlanders who are neighbours have no such 
problems.﻿

comments.text:
Fueron tres largos días de capacitación en el Tec de Monterrey, pero sin 
duda de mucho provecho el conocer, pero también reconocer los cambios en 
materia educativa, los nuevos acercamientos a la enseñanza y la utilización 
de nuevas herramientas, me hacen pensar de un futuro promisorio para las 
nuevas generaciones. El reto es aterrizarlo y difundirlo para que este al 
alcance de las mayorías. Como ejemplo Finlandia. ﻿

comments.author: PoprocksAndCoke777

comments.text:
I really think we should take notes from Finland. Really, my school is 
pitiful. It's embarrassing now. I heard stories of the U.S. once being at 
the top, and now we're all the way down in ranks as low as #16 in one 
subject and #23 and #25 in others. I really don't think teachers should be 
saying "Oh, our methods works". They've obviously proved their methods are 
more efficient than ours. Also, I think there should be other tests where 
you compare your scores during your last year in high school, just to give 
other countries who get a majority of their knowledge in their later years 
a chance. I can honestly say I've seen a significant rise in the skills of 
my classmates over these past 2 years. I'm now a junior.﻿

comments.author: usehername

comments.text:
I'm from Finland and im 13, we have over atleast 5 test a month and i'm in 
seventh grade. We started having tests at second grade and we have private 
schools. I started school when i was 6 BTW. This guy is talking out of his 
ass and he's talking like he's constipated.﻿
comments.author: Ideal

comments.text:
You understood wrong. The testing he refers to does not mean exams. I 
suppose about 99% of Finns go to school at age of 7 and about the same 
number of people does a public school. The number of people who do a 
private school is so small, that we can generalize; there's no private 
schools in Finland. Not so many private schools that it would make any 
significant difference to the PISA result.
comments.author: wopmf4345FxFDxdGaa20

comments.text:
In some rare cases children can start school one year earlier or later, but 
majority will start school in same year when they turn 7. Of course if you 
have born at the end of the year you will start school when you are 6, but 
you will be count as 7 years old because of the birth year. You are right 
that we have some private schools in Finland, but you need to understand 
that private school has totally different meaning in Finland compared to 
rest of the world.
comments.author: Tiuski

comments.text:
You did not quite understand what testing are they referring to. They are 
not talking about the exams. And school does start when you are seven years 
old, very few start before that age. Private schools may exist, but thay 
are so rare that I really do not think they are even worth mentioning. I 
too am from Finland by the way and I am 36 years old.
